Philosophy, and education: journeys from wonder to understanding.

In many cases, the barriers to learning lie in misconceptions; it is  philosophical task to elicit and challenge these, through inquiry.
Asking students to give an account of the meaning of an important concept: a distinctively philosophical task & a great aid to learning.
Philosophical discussion: a potent means of stimulating reflective inquiry and helping clarify students' conceptual frameworks.
@annaworth @daisychristo See https://t.co/eD84D9GQnW and https://t.co/960C2ybYcn for correlation between EPQ and HE entry / degree outcome.

@annaworth @daisychristo Having EPQ or PreU GPR alongside AS/A levels significantly increases probability of attending Russell/1994
grp uni
Philosophical discussion is an antidote to the reduction of education to a soulless regime of spoon-fed training to jump assessment hoops.
Teach students to think for themselves; you thereby teach well, and in the process, hand them the tools for success when they are assessed.
In an age where 'results matter', it takes a certain courage to focus instead on instilling in students a love of learning for its own sake.
Much of what damages education  would be resolved by a determined rejection of the assumption that only measurable outcomes matter.

@mfordhamhistory Roughly: acquiring information involves the formation of a true belief; knowledge requires that the belief be justified.
@EdSacredProfane @mfordhamhistory Excellent question!
@mfordhamhistory Acquiring knowledge involves acquiring justified true belief - which is more than simply acquiring true belief.
@ded6ajd Yes - we reach bedrock and the spade turns, as W said..
@mfordhamhistory Yes.
@mfordhamhistory Roughly: acquisition of information leads to true belief, but knowledge requires (at least) that true belief be justified.
The educational process is a philosophical journey proceeding from information acquisition to knowledge creation & thence understanding.
